**What is this benefit?** Your {{employee_type}} is eligible for emergency leave under terms that depend on the size of the agency, if those terms are better than what they'll receive under FFCRA. **Who pays for it?** Your agency is responsible for any up-front payment needed to cover the emergency leave period, and their insurance should cover any further use of PFL/DB. Depending on your arrangement, some or all of the up-front payment may be your responsibility.

results_benefit_long_nys_work_a_books_c_:
Your {{employee_type}} most likely qualifies for some kind of emergency leave under the new COVID rules for Paid Family Leave and Disability.  The kind of leave available depends on the size of the agency:

* **Small Business** (agencies with 10 or fewer employees as of January 1, 2020, and that had a net annual income less than $1 million last year) must provide job protection for the duration of the quarantine.

* **Medium Business** (agencies with 11-99 employees as of January 1, 2020, and smaller employers that had a net annual income greater than $1 million last year) must provide job protection for the duration of the quarantine, and at least 5 days of paid sick leave at their full pay rate.

* **Large Business** (agencies with 100 or more employees as of January 1, 2020) must provide job protection for the duration of the quarantine, and at least 14 days of paid sick leave.

In most cases, your {{employee_type}} will get better benefits via FFCRA, and should use those instead.  But if they're excluded -- for example, if the agency has 500 or more employees and is not required to provide leave under FFCRA -- not, these benefits can help fill in the gaps.

After they've used the paid sick leave required, they can apply for PFL and DB under the normal rules:

* If your {{employee_type}} works a regular schedule of 20 or more hours per week, they're eligible for PFL after 26 consecutive weeks with your agency.
* If your {{employee_type}} works a regular schedule of less than 20 hours per week, they're eligible for PFL after 175 days with your agency, which don't need to be consecutive.
* If your agency is considered a "covered employer", your {{employee_type}} will be eligible for DB after 4 consecutive weeks.
* If your agency is considered a "covered employer", and your {{employee_type}} previously worked for another covered employer, they're eligible for DB on their first day, assuming they didn't have a gap in coverage.
* If your {{employee_type}} carries their own DB coverage, they'd also be eligible.

PFL must be used first, if available, and provides 10 weeks of coverage at **60%** of their full pay rate, up to a maximum of $840.70/week.

Disability can be used alongside PFL to bring your {{employee_type}} up to their full pay rate. The maximum weekly benefit for PFL and DB together is $2,884.62/week.  After that, DB provides **50%** of their full pay rate for 26 weeks, up to a maximum of $2,043.92/week.

Your {{employee_type}} does not need to apply for emergency leave, but to access PFL/DB benefits, they'll need to:

1. Obtain an [order of quarantine/isolation](http://docs.paidfamilyleave.ny.gov/content/main/forms/PFLDocs/obtain-order-of-quarantine.pdf) from the health department.  If the order is delayed, they can use temporary documentation from a medical provider while waiting. The last section of [this FAQ](https://paidfamilyleave.ny.gov/new-york-paid-family-leave-covid-19-faqs) explains how.

2. Download and fill out [the self-quarantine form packet](http://docs.paidfamilyleave.ny.gov/content/main/forms/PFLDocs/scovid19.pdf) (forms SCOVID19 and PFL-1).

3. Have the agency complete their part of the forms.

4. Submit them to the insurance company.

This benefit does not have any citizenship or immigration status requirements.

1. * A minor child who is under an order of quarantine or isolation from the health department, whether they have contracted COVID-19 or not

* A family member who has contracted COVID-19, which is now considered a serious condition for the purposes of PFL

Whether your {{employee_type}} is eligible for PFL depends on their hours, and how long they've been with the agency:

* If your {{employee_type}} works a regular schedule of 20 or more hours per week, they're eligible for PFL after 26 consecutive weeks with your agency.

* If your {{employee_type}} works a regular schedule of less than 20 hours per week, they're eligible for PFL after 175 days with your agency, which don't need to be consecutive.

PFL provides 10 weeks of coverage at **60%** of their full pay rate, up to a maximum of $840.70/week.

To access PFL/DB benefits, your {{employee_type}} will need to:

1. If they're caring for a minor child, obtain an [order of quarantine/isolation](http://docs.paidfamilyleave.ny.gov/content/main/forms/PFLDocs/obtain-order-of-quarantine.pdf) from the health department. The last section of [this FAQ](https://paidfamilyleave.ny.gov/new-york-paid-family-leave-covid-19-faqs) explains how.

For another family member, download and fill out [the leave request packet](https://paidfamilyleave.ny.gov/pfl-family-care-leave-form) (forms PFL-1, -2, and -3).  Form PFL-2 is a medical release that must be filled out by the family member, and Form PFL-3 is a medical certification that must be filled out by the doctor or other qualifying health care professional.

3. Have the agency complete their part of the forms.

4. Submit them to the insurance company, if your agency has one. If not, the agency should keep them for their records instead.

This benefit does not have any citizenship or immigration status requirements.

If your agency does not extend these benefits, your {{employee_type}} can contact the NY Department of Labor to [submit a complaint](https://www.labor.ny.gov/COVIDcomplaint) and access the benefits anyway. type_h_agency_a_employed_u:
Employees begin to accrue sick and safe leave the first day of employment 


Employers must give employees up to 40 hours of safe and sick leave every calendar year.


Even when the 40 hours are exhausted, employees continue to accrue hours. Up to 40 hours of unused safe and sick leave can be carried over to the next calendar year.


Employees may start using accrued safe leave 120 days after the start of employment.


Employers must allow employees to use safe and sick time for the following reasons:


+ Tend to mental or physical illness, injury, or other health conditions 

+ Care for family members (anyone they consider to be family)

+ Public health emergency 

+ Seek help or take other safety measures for any act or threat of domestic violence, unwanted sexual contact, stalking, or human trafficking



If the use of time is unanticipated, an employer may require notice of absence as soon as practical.  


+ Any procedure or policy regarding the accrual, use and giving notice for paid safe and sick leave must be written. 

+ Employers may only require documentation for absences of more than three consecutive workdays.

+ No documentation is needed when {{employee_type}} takes two day off.

Your {{employee_type}} qualifies for leave under both the Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act and the Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act:

* The Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act provides full regular pay for two weeks, up to 80 hours (e.g., if they normally work 20 hours per week, they would receive 40 hours paid leave), because of their need to self-quarantine.

* The Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act provides an additional ten weeks of leave at 2/3 their regular pay (if they've been with you at least 30 days), because of their child's school closure.

To access this benefit, your employee can request leave either verbally or in writing. You should keep a record of:

* their name,
* the dates they're requesting leave,
* the name of the doctor who advised them to self-quarantine,
* a statement that they are unable to work because of this self-quarantine,
* the name of the child being cared for,
* the name of the school or child care provider that's closed or unavailable,
* and a statement that no other suitable person is able to provide care for the child

They should also provide written documentation from both the doctor and the child care provider.

This benefit does not have any immigration status or minimum work requirements. These provisions last until Dec. 31, 2020.

If you do not extend these benefits, your {{employee_type}} can contact the Wage and Hour Division at the US Department of Labor to submit a complaint and access the benefits anyway.  You would then be subject to an investigation and fines as a result of non-compliance.

If your {{employee_type}} prefers to work off the books, you should continue paying them as long as possible so they can earn some relief.

Your {{employee_type}} is most likely eligible for unemployment benefits, with extra compensation and extended coverage because of the pandemic.  In order to be eligible for unemployment insurance, your {{employee_type}} must:

* have lost work through no fault of their own
* be ready, willing and able to work, were COVID-19 not a factor
* have work authorization
* qualify for pandemic unemployment assistance under [one of these scenarios](https://www.labor.ny.gov/ui/pdfs/pandemic-unemployment-assistance.pdf)

Pandemic unemployment assistance covers your {{employee_type}} for 26 weeks and provides a weekly payment based on their usual rate of pay.  The NY Department of Labor provides a [benefit calculator](https://labor.ny.gov/benefit-rate-calculator/) to help your employee estimate how much they would receive.  Until July 26, 2020, an additional $600 per week will be automatically added to their benefits.  If New York's unemployment rate remains high, extended benefits will be available for another 20 weeks after that.

On your {{employee_type}}'s last day of work, you must provide them with a [Record of Employment](https://www.labor.ny.gov/formsdocs/ui/IA12_3.pdf).  They can start a claim for unemployment without it, but having proper documentation speeds up the process.  They should file in the first week after losing their job.

The DOL has [step-by-step instructions for filing a claim](https://dol.ny.gov/unemployment/file-your-first-claim-benefits). Your {{employee_type}} can apply online or by phone.  Applying online offers the option of receiving payments via direct deposit or by debit card; only debit card is available through the phone system.

The DOL will contact you to verify your {{employee_type}}'s claim and collect any other necessary information. You can help speed up this process by making sure you have all of your {{employee_type}}'s payment records on hand and responding promptly to any requests.  Bear in mind that because DOL representatives are currently working from home, your caller ID might indicate an unlisted number.  They will verify their identity for security before asking you for further information.  Do not give out any of your {{employee_type}}'s private information without this verification.

Please be aware that wait times for unemployment assistance have been quite long, and your {{employee_type}} may need to wait a significant amount of time before receiving any payments.

results_benefit_long_pssl_agency_b_emplo:
Your {{employee_type}} is entitled to two days of leave per calendar year under New York City's Paid Safe and Sick law.  Public emergencies like COVID-19 are considered a valid reason for sick leave, whether your {{employee_type}} is sick, has a sick family member, or is trying to prevent illness.

"Safe" leave was added to the sick leave law in 2018 and covers leave needed to seek help or take safety measures in a set of specific situations, including domestic violence, which has become more common under COVID-19.  [The PSSL FAQ](https://www1.nyc.gov/assets/dca/downloads/pdf/about/PaidSickLeave-FAQs.pdf) includes a fuller definition and example scenarios.

These two days are *in addition* to the three days of rest required under New York State's Domestic Workers Bill of Rights.

You're required to have a leave policy in writing, provided to your {{employee_type}} on employment, after any change to the policy, and on request. Policies must cover things like:

* Advance notice for foreseeable leave (e.g., a doctor's appointment)
* Reasonable notification for unforeseeable leave (e.g., a family member becoming ill)
* Documentation, if the time off is more than two consecutive days

You can find a full list of points your policy needs to address in [the PSSL FAQ](https://www1.nyc.gov/assets/dca/downloads/pdf/about/PaidSickLeave-FAQs.pdf) under "Use of Sick and Safe Leave".

You may have sick and safe policies more generous than what's required by law, but not less.  Your {{employee_type}} can file a complaint with the Department of Consumer affairs if they are not provided with the required leave.

This benefit does not have any citizenship or immigration status requirements.
